skills.name: Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number
Order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
Add proper fractions with the same denominator
Order fractions with the same numerators

explanations.A: 7 is bigger but we are dividing by the 5 and 7. Will the pieces be bigger or smaller if you are dividing into more pieces?
explanations.B: The numerators are equal but the denominators are different. Think about the fractions as divisions, which would be bigger 3 ÷ 5 or 3 ÷ 7?
explanations.C: Fifths are bigger than sevenths but for example 7/7 is bigger than 1/5... What else do you need to talk about in your explanation?
explanations.D: Fifths are bigger than sevenths and there are 3 of each therefore, 3/5 is bigger than 3/7. This explanation is perfect!

explanations.A: The numerators are equal but the denominators are different. Think about the fractions as divisions, which would be bigger 4 ÷ 9 or 4 ÷ 7?
explanations.B: 9 is bigger but we are dividing by the 7 and 9. Will the pieces be bigger or smaller if you are dividing into more pieces?
explanations.C: Sevenths are bigger than ninths and there are 4 of each therefore, 4/7 is bigger than 4/9. This explanation is perfect!
explanations.D: Sevenths are bigger than ninths but for example 9/9 is bigger than 1/7... What else do you need to talk about in your explanation?

explanations.A: Fourths are bigger than fifths but you also have to consider the numerators.
explanations.B: We don't subtract within fractions. 3/4 means 3 ÷ 4 and 4/5 means 4 ÷ 5. What do we need to do to compare fractions with different denominators?
explanations.C: 3/4 means 3 ÷ 4 and 4/5 means 4 ÷ 5. What do we need to do to compare fractions with different denominators?
explanations.D: When we have fractions with different numerators and denominators, the best way to compare them is to find equivalent fractions with a common denominator! Here we can use 20ths as 20 is in both the 4 and 5 times tables. 3/4 = 15/20 and 4/5 = 16/20, 16/20 is bigger therefore, 4/5 is greater!

explanations.A: We don't subtract within fractions. 5/6 means 5 ÷ 6 and 6/7 means 6 ÷ 7. What do we need to do to compare fractions with different denominators?
explanations.B: When we have fractions with different numerators and denominators, the best way to compare them is to find equivalent fractions with a common denominator! Here we can use 42nds as 42 is in both the 6 and 7 times tables. 5/6 = 35/42 and 6/7 = 36/42, 36/42 is bigger therefore, 6/7 is greater!
explanations.C: Sixths are greater than sevenths but you also have to consider the numerators.
explanations.D: 5/6 means 5 ÷ 6 and 6/7 means 6 ÷ 7. What do we need to do to compare fractions with different denominators?

explanations.A: 3 is less than 9, but we are looking at thirds and ninths. When comparing fractions, we need to think about equivalent fractions and common denominators... Do any of these statements do that?
explanations.B: To compare fractions we need a common denominator. 9 is in both the 3 and 9 times tables so we can use this as the common denominator. 1/3 = 3/9 which is less than 4/9. Therefore, statement B is the one used to justify!
explanations.C: We could compare the numerators if both fractions had the same denominator... Use this clue to help you identify the statement we need!
explanations.D: This is a true statement but the numerators are not equal so we cannot simply compare the denominators. Can you find a statement that uses a common denominator and equivalent fractions to compare the values?

explanations.A: To compare fractions we need a common denominator. 12 is in both the 4 and 12 times tables so we can use this as the common denominator. 3/4 = 9/12 which is less than 11/12. Therefore, statement A is the one used to justify!
explanations.B: We could compare the numerators if both fractions had the same denominator... Use this clue to help you identify the statement we need!
explanations.C: This is a true statement but the numerators are not equal so we cannot simply compare the denominators. Can you find a statement that uses a common denominator and equivalent fractions to compare the values?
explanations.D: 4 is less than 12, but we are looking at fourths and twelfths. When comparing fractions, we need to think about equivalent fractions and common denominators... Do any of these statements do that?

explanations.A: 1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4 = 4/4. You are breaking up 4/3 into 4 parts... What would each part be worth?
explanations.B: 4/3 means we have four thirds. There are four boxes therefore we need to put a third in each box as four thirds (1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3) will add together to give 4/3!
explanations.C: I think you have forgotten to decompose: 4/3 + 4/3 + 4/3 + 4/3 = 16/3... You are breaking up 4/3 into 4 parts, what would each part be worth?
explanations.D: 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 4 but we want 4/3... I think you have forgotten to include the denominator!

explanations.A: I think you have accidentally added 4/5 + 4/5 + 4/5 + 4/5 to get 16/5 but the question is asking you to break up 4/5 into four parts... What would each part be worth?
explanations.B: 1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4 = 4/4. You are breaking up 4/5 into 4 parts... What would each part be worth?
explanations.C: I think you have forgotten to decompose: 4/5 + 4/5 + 4/5 + 4/5 = 16/5... You are breaking up 4/5 into 4 parts, what would each part be worth?
explanations.D: 4/5 means we have four fifths. There are four boxes therefore we need to put one fifth in each box as four fifths (1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5) will add together to give 4/5!

explanations.B: 5/3 means we have 5 x 1/3 or five thirds added together. Therefore, 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3 = 5/3!
explanations.C: 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 = 3/5... We want 5/3, can you correct the mistake!?
explanations.D: 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 = 5/5... We want 5/3, can you correct the mistake!?

explanations.A: 6/5 means we have 6 x 1/5 or six fifths added together. Therefore, 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 = 6/5!
explanations.B: 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 = 5/6... We want 6/5, can you correct the mistake!?
explanations.D: 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6 = 6/6... We want 6/5, can you correct the mistake!?
